climate.description: Summer conditions with potential for heat or rain. Variable Wisconsin weather.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through northern Wisconsin Northwoods. Rolling terrain with moderate elevation gain.
features: Mix of maintained and unmaintained roads

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Remote grassroots Wisconsin event. Affordable and authentic but very limited infrastructure.

biased_opinion.summary: Bear 100 is a remote northern Wisconsin gravel century in the Northwoods. Laona is tiny, amenities are minimal, and the field is small. It's an honest grassroots 100-miler for Wisconsin cyclists who want an affordable, low-key challenge in a beautiful forest setting. Don't expect professional organization or competitive depth—this is a local ride that happens to be 100 miles long.
weaknesses: Very remote location with minimal amenities
Tiny field with no competitive depth
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A small grassroots 100-miler in remote northern Wisconsin. Perfect for locals who want an affordable century in the Northwoods. Not worth traveling far for unless you're combining with Wisconsin vacation or visiting the area.

final_verdict.one_liner: Remote grassroots Wisconsin century in the Northwoods.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Only if you're in Wisconsin and want an affordable, low-key 100-miler in a beautiful setting. Not worth traveling far for.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Wisconsin events: Driftless Gravel, Chequamegon. For similar grassroots centuries: regional Midwest gravel events.

logistics.airport: Green Bay (GRB) or Milwaukee (MKE) 3-4 hours drive
logistics.lodging_strategy: Very limited lodging in Laona. Look for nearby towns or camping. Book early.
logistics.food: Small town with minimal dining. Stock up beforehand.

marketplace_variables.race_hook: 100 miles of northern Wisconsin Northwoods gravel.
marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: Grassroots century in remote Laona with rolling forest terrain.

logistics.explanation: The race database shows community data mixed between two different Bear 100 events - a Wisconsin gravel race and a Utah trail ultra. Steve Bremner describes "21,000 feet of elevation gain" while Miles4Hips Runner cites "22,518 feet," both impossible for a Wisconsin cycling event with 3,500 feet listed. Course reroutes happen with minimal notice - Sarah Vlach notes "Due to reroute, I was going to be without pacer through the night" after changes 24 hours before race start.

length.explanation: Five route options from 18-mile Friday pre-ride to 113-mile sufferfest accommodate all levels, with Laona Rescue Squad support ending at 7 PM sharp. Ted's competitive approach paid off: "I made my way up the first climb somewhere around 25th place, and ultimately reeled in nearly 20 people who went out in front but couldn't hang on." Anna Frost completed her distance in 20:59, showing the courses challenge experienced racers while welcoming newcomers. Longer than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

technicality.explanation: Miles4Hips Runner found conditions manageable: "The trails were less technical and less steep than many of the trails that I have trained on making me feel strong and confident. And the downhills were pleasantly runnable." The 3 miles of easy singletrack on Strong Falls Trails plus varied gravel through Nicolet National Forest creates accessible terrain. Equipment selection matters on rutted sections like the notorious Deer Lake Cut-off Road two-track. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: The 3,500 feet over 100 miles delivers rolling Wisconsin forest terrain without major sustained climbs. Course winds through Nicolet National Forest connecting to regional high points as part of the Ironbear 1000 series. The manageable elevation profile suits both gravel-curious first-timers on shorter routes and seasoned veterans tackling the full century distance with family-friendly climbing throughout. Less climbing than The Mid South. As Ted puts it: "On the mountainous course that climbs 22,000 vertical feet through the Wasatch/ Bear River Range of Northern Utah and Idaho, I finished in 22 hours and 22 minutes. That was good enough for 8th place."

climate.explanation: Early May northern Wisconsin brings dramatic temperature swings from 31°F overnight frost to 85°F midday heat. Steve Bremner experienced the full range: "grueling afternoon under a hot sun" followed by "31 degrees. Frost. Slight wind" during night sections. Anna Frost dealt with humid morning starts and "rain forecast for midnight, which arrived as promised," requiring gear management skills for changing conditions. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Northern Wisconsin lowland forest terrain around Laona sits near typical Midwest elevations without oxygen concerns. The course connects regional high points through the Ironbear 1000 series but remains in lowland forest throughout. Starting and finishing in a population-400 town, altitude effects remain negligible for this Great Lakes region gravel event. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Hidden gravel roads through Nicolet National Forest plus the 7 PM support cutoff creates consequence for route selection. Trail markings proved sparse during Steve Bremner's race: "Trail markings sparse and infrequent... Those pink ribbons on the trail were absolutely helpful. Apparently some hunters had diabolically removed markers." Creek crossings and varied forest terrain add adventure, but within accessible gravel parameters for most riders.

prestige.explanation: A charity ride in population-400 Laona explicitly marketed to "gravel curious first timers" and families, with youth 16 and under riding free. The 12-year tradition focuses on supporting Laona Rescue Squad rather than competitive racing. Ted finished 8th in 22:22, showing solid performances happen, but the event's identity centers on accessibility and community fundraising over racing prestige.

race_quality.explanation: Performance Timing provides professional chip timing with soup at the finish, but organizational communication stays minimal. Ted managed aid stations efficiently: "There were 13 aid stations on the course and my cumulative time at them was just 31 minutes" over his 22:22 finish. Course changes happen based on spring conditions with short notice, focusing on execution over detailed participant communication.

experience.explanation: Nicolet National Forest's hidden gravel plus 3 miles of easy singletrack on Strong Falls Trails delivers classic Wisconsin forest riding. The infamous Deer Lake Cut-off Road provides rutty two-track punishment, while creek crossings add variety. Steve Bremner's experience included navigation challenges: "Creek crossing... I couldn't do that with my lack of balance... Finally I just wade across." The 7 PM support cutoff adds consequence to longer route selections.

community.explanation: Twelve years of tradition in tiny Laona creates a small-town gathering with 100% of proceeds supporting Laona Rescue Squad equipment and training. The event welcomes families with youth riding free and e-bikes on shorter routes. Ted's strategic racing approach shows competitive riders attend: "I started up front, but behind the leaders... and ultimately reeled in nearly 20 people." The charitable focus and accessibility balance with performance opportunities.

field_depth.explanation: Ted's 8th place finish in 22:22 represents solid performance, but the event explicitly welcomes "gravel curious first timers" rather than deep competitive fields. Youth 16 and under ride free with family-friendly shorter routes positioning the race as accessible entry point. The charitable mission supporting Laona Rescue Squad draws community participation over racing depth. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder.

value.explanation: Five distance options from 18 to 113 miles with Performance Timing's professional chip timing, plus your registration supports Laona Rescue Squad instead of promoter profits. Youth 16 and under ride free with adult supervision, and e-bikes welcome on family routes. Ted's aid station experience shows solid support: "There were 13 aid stations on the course" providing comprehensive coverage for the charitable entry fee.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $60-100. Laona's population-400 small-town Wisconsin location delivers affordable lodging and food without inflated race weekend pricing typical of urban events. The northern Wisconsin forest setting avoids expensive metropolitan costs, while the charitable race structure keeps fees reasonable. Miles4Hips Runner's gear strategy shows typical expenses: planned hiking poles from start but "forgot my hiking poles at the house" - simple equipment needs for accessible terrain. More affordable than Crusher in the Tushar.

primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

videos.title: The Bear Gravel Race - 2022
videos.description:
Only the first ~21 miles of The Bear 100 (72 miles). I was in the front group when I crashed out and took my first ride in an ambulance. On the plus side, I got to experience the Laona Rescue Squad first hand, which was somewhat fitting as The Bear is their fundraiser :).
Recap video: https://youtu.be/PH4neyFGE7s

quotes.text: There were some times where we had some uphills and different things like that and it was a very, very cool atmosphere and cool setting for a gravel race here in northern Wisconsin. These roads I would say overall decent condition. They did have a fair amount of rain here the night before. So, the roads were rather wet and sticky and at times a lot of potholes and puddles.

There's usually a section of what they call ruddy twotrack at the end. It's just mud really. It's like an ATV trail with deep, thick, slushy mud. They took it out this year because there was an inch of rain a week before the race and they said it was not safe.

This section here where we start to go up some of these hills with the pines and birch trees here on the sides of the road. This is honestly one of my favorite parts of the course. It's just beautiful and really accentuates what Wisconsin has to offer for gravel riding.
